abstract.p: New garden at Musee Cluny in Paris is meant for education and relaxation; photo (S)

block.p: Built on the relics of Roman baths in the 15th century, the elaborate medieval cloister of the Musee Cluny, the French national museum of the Middle Ages, has made a 21st-century addition, a garden meant for education and relaxation. ''In the Middle Ages, man was in communion with nature,'' one of the garden's architects, Eric Ossart, said. Mr. Ossart and Arnaud Maurieres, working in tandem on the project, used the museum's rich collection as the principal inspiration. The garden's wood catwalks allow visitors close to the plant beds, which are divided into four groups: plants for cooking (cabbage, garlic, onion); medicinal plants (sage, hyssop, mint); flowers (roses, iris, violets), and a love garden (topiaries, perfumed grass). The Musee National du Moyen Age is at 6 place Paul-Painleve, at Boulevards St. Germain and St. Michel; 011-33.1.53.73.78.00; www.musee-moyenage.fr
